value_mask.mask: Percent of memory for application group heap
Application control heap size
Maximum size of application group memory set
determines the virtual memory that is allocated by DB2 for each agent.

is deprecated in Version 9.5, but is still being used by pre-Version 9.5 data servers and clients. Any value specified for this configuration parameter will continue to work exactly as it did in previous versions, and will continue to be fully supported. If is used for workload management (WLM), then the WLM service class agent priority will be ignored.

The application support layer heap represents a communication buffer between the local application and its associated agent. This buffer is allocated as shared memory by each database manager agent that is started.
specifies the size of the buffer used when auditing the database.
specifies and determines how and where authentication of a user takes place.
specifies whether users are able to catalog and uncatalog databases and nodes, or DCS and ODBC directories, without SYSADM authority.
specifies the name of the default Kerberos plug-in library to be used for client-side authentication and local authorization.
specifies the name of the userid-password plug-in library to be used for client-side authentication and local authorization.
enables the database manager to communicate incremental cluster configuration changes to the specified cluster manager.
helps the query optimizer determine access paths by indicating the bandwidth between database partition servers.
specifies the number of seconds within which a TCP/IP connection is to be established between two database partition servers.
reflects the CPU speed of the machine(s) the database is installed on.
acts as the default suffix of accounting identifiers.
allows you to set a number of switches which are each internally represented by a bit of the parameter.
Snapshot monitor bufferpool information recording switch.
Snapshot monitor lock information recording switch.
Snapshot monitor sort information recording switch.
Snapshot monitor statement information recording switch.
Snapshot monitor table information recording switch.
Snapshot monitor timestamp information recording switch.
Snapshot monitor unit of work information recording switch.

contains the default file path used to create databases under the database manager. If no path is specified when a database is created, the database is created under the path specified by the dftdbpath parameter.
specifies the type of diagnostic errors that will be recorded in the db2diag.log file.
allows you to specify the fully qualified path for DB2 diagnostic information.
determines whether the database, node and DCS directory files will be cached in memory.
determines what kind of discovery requests, if any, the client can make.
specifies whether this instance can be detected by DB2 discovery.
specifies the number of 4 KB buffers that are used for internal communications (messages) both among and within database servers.
specifies the number of FCM channels for each database partition.
determines whether federated authentication will be bypassed at the instance.
enables or disables support for applications submitting distributed requests for data managed by data sources (such as the DB2 Family and Oracle).
determines the maximum number of asynchrony table queues (ATQs) in the access plan that the federated server supports.

represents the number of threads cached in each db2fmp process for threaded db2fmp processes (processes serving threadsafe stored procedures and UDFs). For nonthreaded db2fmp processes, represents the number of processes cached.
specifies the name of the group plug-in library.
allows you to specify whether you want to monitor an instance, its associated databases, and database objects according to various health indicators.
indicates when the database manager will attempt to rebuild invalid indexes, and whether or not any index build will be redone during DB2 rollforward or HADR log replay on the standby database.
specifies the maximum amount of memory that can be allocated for a database partition.
specifies whether the database manager can use intra-partition parallelism.
determines the maximum size of the heap that is used by the Java interpreter started to service Java DB2 stored procedures and UDFs.

specifies the directory under which the Software Developer's Kit (SDK) for Java, to be used for running Java stored procedures and user-defined functions, is installed. The CLASSPATH and other environment variables used by the Java interpreter are computed from the value of this parameter.">jdk_path - Software Developer's Kit for Java installation path configuration parameter

indicates whether or not a fenced mode process is kept after a fenced mode routine call is complete. Fenced mode processes are created as separate system entities in order to isolate user-written fenced mode code from the database manager agent process. is only applicable on database servers.

specifies the name of the default GSS API plug-in library to be used for instance level local authorization when the value of the authentication database manager configuration parameter is set to GSSPLUGIN or GSS_SERVER_ENCRYPT.
indicates the maximum number of client connections allowed per database partition.
specifies the maximum number of times an attempt will be made to establish a TCP/IP connection between two database partition servers.
is used to limit the number of coordinating agents.

specifies the maximum degree of intra-partition parallelism that is used for any SQL statement executing on this instance of the database manager. An SQL statement will not use more than this number of parallel operations within a database partition when the statement is executed.
specifies the maximum time difference, in minutes, that is permitted among the database partition servers listed in the node configuration file.

determines the amount of the memory, in pages, to allocate for database system monitor data. Memory is allocated from the monitor heap when you perform database monitoring activities such as taking a snapshot, turning on a monitor switch, resetting a monitor, or activating an event monitor.
specifies the type of administration notification messages that are written to the administration notification log.
determines the initial number of idle agents that are created in the agent pool at DB2START time.
indicates the initial number of nonthreaded, idle db2fmp processes that are created in the db2fmp pool at DB2START time.
sets the maximum size of the idle agent pool.

specifies the number of local databases that can be concurrently active (that is, have applications connected to them), or the maximum number of different database aliases that can be cataloged on a DB2 Connect server.

is deprecated in Version 9.5, but is still being used by pre-Version 9.5 data servers and clients. Any value specified for this configuration parameter will be ignored by the DB2 Version 9.5 database manager.

specifies the time interval in seconds for which a transaction manager (TM), resource manager (RM) or sync point manager (SPM) should retry the recovery of any outstanding indoubt transactions found in the TM, the RM, or the SPM. is applicable when you have transactions running in a distributed unit of work (DUOW) environment. also applies to recovery of federated database systems.

specifies the size of the communication buffer between remote applications and their database agents on the database server. It is also used to determine the I/O block size at the Data Server Runtime Client when a blocking cursor is opened.">rqrioblk - Client I/O block size configuration parameter

is an instance-wide soft limit on the total amount of memory that can be consumed by private sorts at any given time. When the total private sort memory consumption for an instance reaches this limit, the memory allocated for additional incoming private sort requests is considerably reduced.
identifies the sync point manager (SPM) log file size in 4 KB pages.
specifies the directory where the sync point manager (SPM) logs are written.
identifies the number of agents that can simultaneously perform resync operations.
identifies the name of the sync point manager (SPM) instance to the database manager.
specifies how and where user authentication is to take place when handling incoming connections at the server; it is used to override the current authentication type.

specifies the GSS API plug-in libraries that are supported by the database server. It handles incoming connections at the server when the srvcon_auth parameter is specified as KERBEROS, KRB_SERVER_ENCRYPT, GSSPLUGIN or GSS_SERVER_ENCRYPT, or when srvcon_auth is not specified, and authentication is specified as KERBEROS, KRB_SERVER_ENCRYPT, GSSPLUGIN or GSS_SERVER_ENCRYPT.
specifies whether plug-ins are to run in fenced mode or unfenced mode. Unfenced mode is the only supported mode.

specifies the name of the default userid-password plug-in library to be used for server-side authentication. It handles incoming connections at the server when the srvcon_auth parameter is specified as CLIENT, SERVER, SERVER_ENCRYPT, or DATA_ENCRYPT or when srvcon_auth is not specified, and authentication is specified as CLIENT, SERVER, SERVER_ENCRYPT, or DATA_ENCRYPT.

specifies the time, in minutes, within which all database partition servers must respond to a DB2START or a DB2STOP command. It is also used as the timeout value during an ADD DBPARTITIONNUM operation.

contains the name of the TCP?IP port which a database server will use to await communications from remote client nodes. This name must be the reserved for use by the database manager.">svcename - TCP/IP service name configuration parameter
defines the group name with SYSADM authority for the database manager instance.
defines the group name with system control (SYSCTRL) authority. SYSCTRL has privileges allowing operations affecting system resources, but does not allow direct access to data.
defines the group name with system maintenance (SYSMAINT) authority.
defines the group name with system monitor (SYSMON) authority.
identifies the name of the transaction manager (TM) database for each DB2 instance.
identifies the name of the transaction processing (TP) monitor product being used.
and trust_clntauth are used to determine where users are validated to the database environment.

specifies whether a trusted client is authenticated at the server or the client when the client provides a userid and password combination for a connection. (and trust_allclnts) is only active if the authentication parameter is set to CLIENT. If a user ID and password are not provided, the client is assumed to have validated the user, and no further validation is performed at the server.
allows the database administrator (DBA) to limit the performance degradation of a throttled utility on the workload.
provides information about the DB2 products which you have installed on your machine and, as a result, information about the type of database manager configuration.
specifies the release level of the configuration file.
specifies the collating sequence that is to be used for Unicode tables in a non-Unicode database.

In previous releases, the applheapsz database configuration parameter referred to the amount of application memory each individual database agent working for that application could consume. With Version 9.5, applheapsz refers to the total amount of application memory that can be consumed by the entire application. For DPF, Concentrator, or SMP configurations, this means that the applheapsz value used in previous releases may need to be increased under similar workloads, unless the AUTOMATIC setting is used.

allows DBAs and ISVs to control the maximum amount of application memory that is allocated by DB2 database agents to service application requests. By default, its value is set to AUTOMATIC, meaning that all application memory requests will be allowed as long as the total amount of memory allocated by the database partition is within the instance_memory limits.
specifies the number of seconds to wait after a failed archive attempt before trying to archive the log file again.
Automatic maintenance configuration parameter
Automatic maintenance configuration parameter
Automatic maintenance configuration parameter
Automatic maintenance configuration parameter
Automatic maintenance configuration parameter
Automatic maintenance configuration parameter
Automatic maintenance configuration parameter
Automatic maintenance configuration parameter
specifies whether database log files, backup images, and load copy images should be deleted when their associated recovery history file entry is pruned.
determines whether the database manager can, in the event of an abnormal termination of the database, automatically call the restart database utility when an application connects to a database.
is used by the query optimizer to help estimate how much buffer pool will be available at run-time for the access plan chosen.
can be set to prevent disk full errors from being generated when DB2 cannot create a new log file in the active log path.
specifies the maximum space in pages that the catalog cache can use from the database heap.
specifies the level (percentage) of changed pages at which the asynchronous page cleaners will be started, if they are not currently active.

specifies the amount of memory that is reserved for the database shared memory region. If this amount is less than the amount calculated from the individual memory parameters (for example, locklist, utility heap, bufferpools, and so on), the larger amount will be used.
determines the maximum memory used by the database heap.

represents the maximum percentage of committed, but currently unused, database shared memory that the database manager will allow before starting to release committed pages of memory back to the operating system.
allows you to specify the rounding mode for decimal floating point (DECFLOAT). The rounding mode affects decimal floating-point operations in the server, and in LOAD.
specifies the default value for the CURRENT DEGREE special register and the DEGREE bind option.
sets the default extent size of table spaces.
specifies the default number of sessions that will be used during the recovery of a table load.

specifies the default value for the CURRENT MAINTAINED TABLE TYPES FOR OPTIMIZATION special register. The value of this register determines what types of refresh deferred materialized query tables will be used during query optimization.
sets the default prefetch size of table spaces.

The query optimization class is used to direct the optimizer to use different degrees of optimization when compiling SQL and XQuery queries. provides additional flexibility by setting the default query optimization class used when neither the SET CURRENT QUERY OPTIMIZATION statement nor the QUERYOPT option on the bind command are used.

represents the maximum time duration since a REFRESH TABLE statement has been processed on a specific REFRESH DEFERRED materialized query table. After this time limit is exceeded, the materialized query table is not used to satisfy queries until the materialized query table is refreshed.
sets the default value that determines the handling of arithmetic errors and retrieval conversion errors as errors or warnings during SQL statement compilation.
is used to prevent information about a database from being returned to a client when a discovery request is received at the server.
defines the frequency at which the database manager checks for deadlocks among all the applications connected to a database.
determines whether Query Patroller will capture information about submitted queries.
determines whether XMLPARSE operations can be performed on non-BIT DATA CHAR (or CHAR-type) expressions in an SQL statement.

specifies a path to which DB2 will try to archive log files if the log files cannot be archived to either the primary or the secondary (if set) archive destinations because of a media problem affecting those destinations. This specified path must reference a disk.
specifies the local host for high availability disaster recovery (HADR) TCP communication.
specifies the TCP service name or port number for which the local high availability disaster recovery (HADR) process accepts connections.

When you set hadr_peer_window to a non-zero time value, then a HADR primary-standby database pair continues to behave as though still in peer state, for the configured amount of time, if the primary database loses connection with the standby database. This helps ensure data consistency.
specifies the TCP/IP host name or IP address of the remote high availability disaster recovery (HADR) database server.

specifies the instance name of the remote server. Administration tools, such as the DB2 Control Center, use to contact the remote server. High availability disaster recovery (HADR) also checks whether a remote database requesting a connection belongs to the declared remote instance.
specifies the TCP service name or port number that will be used by the remote high availability disaster recovery (HADR) database server.
specifies the synchronization mode, which determines how primary log writes are synchronized with the standby when the systems are in peer state.
specifies the time (in seconds) that the high availability disaster recovery (HADR) process waits before considering a communication attempt to have failed.
indicates when the database manager will attempt to rebuild invalid indexes, and whether or not any index build will be redone during DB2 rollforward or HADR log replay on the standby database.
indicates the amount of storage that is allocated to the lock list. There is one lock list per database and it contains the locks held by all applications concurrently connected to the database.
specifies the number of seconds that an application will wait to obtain a lock, helping avoid global deadlocks for applications.
specifies the media type of the primary destination for archived logs.
specifies the media type of the secondary destination for archived logs.
specifies the options field for the primary destination for archived logs (if required).
specifies the options field for the secondary destination for archived logs (if required).
allows you to specify the amount of the database heap (defined by the dbheap parameter) to use as a buffer for log records before writing these records to disk.

defines the size of each primary and secondary log file. The size of these log files limits the number of log records that can be written to them before they become full and a new log file is required.

specifies whether index creation, recreation, or reorganization operations are to be logged so that indexes can be reconstructed during DB2 rollforward operations or high availability disaster recovery (HADR) log replay procedures.
allows you to specify the number of primary log files to be preallocated. The primary log files establish a fixed amount of storage allocated to the recovery log files.

is deprecated in Version 9.5, but is still being used by pre-Version 9.5 data servers and clients. Any value specified for this configuration parameter will be ignored by the DB2 Version 9.5 database manager.
specifies the number of secondary log files that are created and used for recovery log files (only as needed).
specifies if there is a limit to the percentage of log space that a transaction can consume, and what that limit is.

specifies the maximum number of concurrent applications that can be connected (both local and remote) to a database. Since each application that attaches to a database causes some private memory to be allocated, allowing a larger number of concurrent applications will potentially use more memory.
specifies the maximum number of file handles that can be open for each database.
defines a percentage of the lock list held by an application that must be filled before the database manager performs lock escalation.
is provided as a quick way to enable a change to computation of the scale for decimal division in SQL.
allows you to delay the writing of log records to disk until a minimum number of commits have been performed, helping reduce the database manager overhead associated with writing log records.
allows you to specify a string of up to 242 bytes for the mirror log path. The string must point to a path name, and it must be a fully qualified path name, not a relative path name.
allows you to specify a string of up to 242 bytes to change the location where the log files are stored.
specifies the number of database backups to retain for a database.
allows you to specify the number of most frequent values that will be collected when the WITH DISTRIBUTION option is specified on the RUNSTATS command.
allows you to specify the number of asynchronous page cleaners for a database.

specifies the number of I/O servers for a database. No more than this number of I/Os for prefetching and utilities can be in progress for a database at any time.">num_ioservers - Number of I/O servers configuration parameter
specifies whether there is a limit to how many log files one transaction can span, and what that limit is.
controls the number of quantiles that will be collected when the WITH DISTRIBUTION option is specified on the RUNSTATS command.
specifies the number of times that DB2 is to try archiving a log file to the primary or the secondary archive directory before trying to archive log files to the failover directory.

specifies a location for DB2 to find log files needed for a rollforward operation, as well as where to store active log files retrieved from the archive. It also gives a location for finding and storing log files needed for using db2ReadLog API.
is allocated out of the database shared memory, and is used for caching of sections for static and dynamic SQL and XQuery statements on a database.
specifies the number of days that historical information on backups will be retained.
determines whether the memory tuner will dynamically distribute available memory resources as required between memory consumers that are enabled for self-tuning.
controls whether the database manager is allowed to detect sequential page reading during I/O activity.
represents a soft limit on the total amount of database shared memory that can be used by sort memory consumers at any one time.
determines the frequency of soft checkpoints and the recovery range, which help out in the crash recovery process.
defines the maximum number of private memory pages to be used for private sorts, or the maximum number of shared memory pages to be used for shared sorts.
indicates the maximum size of the heap used in collecting statistics using the RUNSTATS command.
specifies the size of the statement heap, which is used as a work space for the SQL or XQuery compiler during compilation of an SQL or XQuery statement.

specifies whether the database manager will track database modifications so that the backup utility can detect which subsets of the database pages must be examined by an incremental backup and potentially included in the backup image.
The Tivoli Storage Manager management class determines how the TSM server should manage the backup versions of the objects being backed up.
is used to override the default setting for the node name associated with the Tivoli Storage Manager (TSM) product.
is used to override the default setting for the owner associated with the Tivoli Storage Manager (TSM) product.
is used to override the default setting for the password associated with the Tivoli Storage Manager (TSM) product.

is deprecated in Version 9.5, but is still being used by pre-Version 9.5 data servers and clients. Any value specified for this configuration parameter will be ignored by the DB2 Version 9.5 database manager.
indicates the maximum amount of memory that can be used simultaneously by the BACKUP, RESTORE, and LOAD (including load recovery) utilities.
specifies additional parameters that DB2 might need to use to communicate with storage systems during backup, restore, or load copy operations.<
specifies a collect and reset interval, in minutes, for workload management (WLM) statistics.
indicates whether you need to do a full backup of the database before accessing it.
shows the code page that was used to create the database. The codepage parameter is derived based on the codeset parameter.
shows the codeset that was used to create the database. Codeset is used by the database manager to determine codepage parameter values.
determines the database's collating sequence. For a language-aware collation, the first 256 bytes contain the string representation of the collation name (for example, "SYSTEM_819_US").
shows the territory code used to create the database.">country/region - Database territory code configuration parameter
indicates whether the database is in a consistent state.
indicates the release level of the database manager which can use the database.
indicates the current role of a database, whether the database is online or offline.
If set (when the logretain parameter setting is equal to Recovery), indicates that log files are being retained for use in roll-forward recovery.
contains the name of the log file that is currently active.
contains the current path being used for logging purposes.

Multipage file allocation is used to improve insert performance. It applies to SMS table spaces only. If enabled, all SMS table spaces are affected: there is no selection possible for individual SMS table spaces.

is deprecated in Version 9.5, but is still being used by pre-Version 9.5 data servers and clients. Any value specified for this configuration parameter will be ignored by the DB2 Version 9.5 database manager.

contains the value that was used as the default page size when the database was created. Possible values are: 4 096, 8 192, 16 384 and 32 768. When a buffer pool or table space is created in that database, the same default page size applies.
specifies the release level of the configuration file.
states whether a RESTORE PENDING status exists in the database.
indicates whether the database was created using the restrictive set of default actions. In other words, if it was created with the RESTRICTIVE clause in the CREATE DATABASE command.
informs you whether or not a roll-forward recovery is required, and where it is required.
shows the territory used to create the database. territory is used by the database manager when processing data that is territory sensitive.

If set to On, indicates that the database manager is enabled for roll-forward recovery and that the user exit program will be used to archive and retrieve log files when called by the database manager.
determines how and where authentication of a user takes place.
specifies the location where the contact information used for notification by the Scheduler and the Health Monitor is stored.
indicates the code page used by the DB2 administration server.
shows the territory used by the DB2 administration server.
defines the group name with DAS Administration (DASADM) authority for the DAS.
specifies the name that is used by your users and database administrators to identify the DB2 server system.
determines the type of discovery mode that is started when the DB2 Administration Server starts.
specifies whether or not the Scheduler will execute tasks that have been scheduled in the past, but have not yet been executed.

specifies the directory under which the 64-Bit Software Developer's Kit (SDK) for Java, to be used for running DB2 administration server functions, is installed.">jdk_64_path - 64-Bit Software Developer's Kit for Java installation path DAS configuration parameter

specifies the directory under which the Software Developer's Kit (SDK) for Java, to be used for running DB2 administration server functions, is installed.">jdk_path - Software Developer's Kit for Java installation path DAS configuration parameter
indicates whether or not the Scheduler is started by the administration server.
specifies the user ID used by the Scheduler to connect to the tools catalog database. is only relevant if the tools catalog database is remote to the DB2 administration server.
When the Scheduler is on, identifies the SMTP server that the Scheduler will use to send e-mail and pager notifications.
indicates the tools catalog database used by the Scheduler.
indicates the instance name that is used by the Scheduler, along with toolscat_db and toolscat_schema, to identify the tools catalog database.
indicates the schema of the tools catalog database used by the Scheduler.
Monitoring activity metrics configuration parameter.
Monitoring deadlock configuration parameter.
Monitoring lock timeout configuration parameter.
Monitoring lock wait configuration parameter.
Monitoring lock wait threshold configuration parameter.
Monitoring lock event notification messages configuration parameter.
Monitoring data object metrics configuration parameter.
Monitoring package list size configuration parameter.
Monitoring request metrics configuration parameter.
Monitoring unit of work events configuration parameter.
Workload management collection interval.
Automatic revalidation and invalidation..
